Regional taxes, well, regions are free to apply taxes, but the constitutional Supreme Court then says that they are not legitimate and that's the end of it. Some years ago, a rate of this kind was imposed by Extremadura and the constitutional court said that they couldn't do it. They will try it again and will go back to court.

Regarding the deficit, well, I don't know whether the tariffs are going to go up or not, but we have the Treasury guarantee. The Treasury guarantee is there to guarantee to the buyers of that deficit that if the system doesn't provide enough money to pay them, the Treasury will pay for the rest and that's the Treasury guarantee.

But in any case, again, the spirit and the law is that in 2013 and this is being re-ratified will put an end to that deficit. There are several elements that have also caused a negative effect. A drop in demand like last year's means that all the forecasts shot up.

If you have more costly output and less demand, fewer people paying for it, paying for the fixed cost, the deficit goes up. If demand goes up, as it's going up this year at a rate of four-point-something percent, the income goes up and therefore, there's more to serve that whole issue. Regarding the U.K.?

With regard to margins in the liberalized business in the U.K., as you'll know, in the first quarter of 2010, the six big players in the U.K. market cut their gas prices by an average of about 8%. Since then, wholesale gas prices have risen in 2010, wholesale gas prices by about 40% and wholesale power prices by about 25%.

So in answer to your question and restoration of margins, I would have thought that the next – the momentum is gathering quite strongly for an upward move in retail prices at some point in 2010, and you've already seen it by some of the pricing activity in our online products in the U.K. market.

Yes, regarding the minority expenses, the impact is around €45 million, but what we do need to repeat and I want to explain it again, Alberto, is that this is an impact that's going to be absorbed. First of all, because this positive impact in the accounts is reflected negatively in the valuation of the financial derivatives. Therefore, one thing is linked to the other. And in the end, both this and the financial derivatives are reflecting the present value of cash flows that haven't taken place yet, and they will come into the company over the next six months, if the exchange rates stay at their current level.

In other words when you're evaluating hedging of financial derivatives, et cetera, regardless of where you put them, in financial expenses or minority expenses, you're bringing in the present value plus the temporary value of the financial derivatives and you take them to the operating accounts at Month Six. And yet in that P&L, you're not reflecting what the group is going to benefit through the greater cash flow that is received by having the flows in appreciated currencies. Therefore, the impact is 45. It has a negative impact on financial results, and that impact over the year has to be offset through other positive cash flows. So therefore, I wouldn't look at it as non-recurrent.
The next person is Javier Suarez from UniCredit. Yes, go ahead, Javier Suarez, with your question please.

Yes, good morning everyone. Javier Suarez from UniCredit. Three questions, the first about the distribution business, on Page 26, you mentioned that in the EBITDA for the is €539 million. Doesn't include investments during 2009.The question is, what will the corrected EBITDA be, including the investments made in 2009?

The second question regarding the Latin American business, on page 31, I think, EBITDA is growing by 15%. And the fact is mentioned, our increase in demand in Brazil and Mexico and the appreciation of the real. Can you give us a figure on the underlying growth in local currency to try to see how sustainable this growth is in Latin America, which has been so good during the first half of the year?

The third question, going back to the regulation issue, we've covered practically all the points, but I would like to have your opinion on the situation regarding the approval of the decree that could force the Spanish electricity sector to consume domestic coal? There are significant difficulties in Europe, and I would like to hear you comment on this. And another detail on Page 33, I think it is, the provision level for the company goes up significantly by more than €70 million compared to the first half of 2009. I would like to know the reasons for this. Thank you.

I'll answer the coal question. The news we have is what's in the press; that the commission has held several meetings, competition, energy, environment and the theme presented by Spain has been postponed for discussion until September. And there does seem to be an agreement, so that coal aid will not be provided and non-competitive mines will have to be closed before October 2014, I think it is.

In Spain, apart from the aid within the electricity tariff, there are €900-odd million in the state budget for aid for mining regions. And if I understand it properly and I read about it in the newspaper, I believe that they want to put an end to this kind of aid, those that are provided through the state budget or those that are provided through the electricity bill.

And in the specific case of the Royal Decree that they wanted to pass to provide incentives for the consumption of domestic coal, well, the discussion has again be postponed until September, because it seems that there is no unanimity or clarity in the approach of the community authorities. Would you like to comment on distribution, José Lu?

Yes. This – it's not only that, but they haven't recognized the investments of the divestitures of 2008 and what they should do is update the remuneration of 2009 and the investments of 2009 should update the remuneration of 2010. And all of this together, which would be the updating of 2009 with investments of 2009 and those of 2010 with those of 2008 and 2009. And in this manner it would be possible to generate an increase in income between million in the case of IBERDROLA and this is with data, data that have been released by the National Energy Commission when it revalidated its reference model.
Would you talk – could you say something about Latin America and provisions?

Well, as far as Latin America is concerned, the growth of the recurrent business in Brazil is something like 10 to 12% and basically this arises from 1.5% growth in demand plus a slight improvement in the margins of the distributor. We have some positive effects on the rates of exchange and although we have had some negative effects because of the sale of assets in Chile, that is not making contribution this year and some non-recurrent effects that have increased expenses relative to the previous year. But so that you can have an idea, the magnitudes of the businesses have produced growth of 10 to 12%, excluding all of those impacts in Brazil. And in Mexico, we also have the same growth, we – it's something like 10.

We've grown little bit less because of the negative rate of exchange and this has reduced the figure to eight. As regards provisions, well, if you remember, in the second – or in the first semester of last year, rather, there was a reversal of provisions and that meant that the level of provisions was abnormally low in the first semester of 2009. So this year, we have a level of provision which is reasonable, but some non-recurrence, as we always do, but it's a reasonable level. But what happened is that last year, we had a number of reversals that have lowered the level of provisions.

Well, after one hour and 45 minutes of presentation, we have to finish unfortunately, my apologies to those that have been waiting on the telephone and on the website, but the department of investments will answer the questions and Ignacio, you have the floor.

Thank you once again and I hope that your biggest concerns about the regulatory issue or deficits or results we've tried to make this as clear as transparent as possible too. Thank you very much and I hope to see you again soon. I hope you enjoy this summer. Thank you.
